name: Giuga number
rephrased: A Giuga number is a composite number that is divisible by the sum of its prime factors each raised to the power of their multiplicity, minus one, for each distinct prime factor.
implication_form: If n is a composite number such that for every distinct prime factor p of n, p divides (n/p - 1), then n is a Giuga number.
explained: In number theory, a Giuga number is a composite number \( n \) that satisfies the following condition: for every distinct prime factor \( p_i \) of \( n \), \( p_i \) divides \( \left( \frac{n}{p_i} - 1 \right) \). This property defines a specific class of composite numbers rather than posing a traditional conjecture about unproven statements. The definition itself is the core concept, and the search for and characterization of such numbers form the subject matter.
related_conjectures: Lario-Santos conjecture (relates Giuga numbers to the abc conjecture)
Ormstadt conjecture (relates to the infinitude of primitive Giuga numbers)
